951.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   "Solid Waste"; means "Municipal Solid Waste" and is a term of art in
the business: garbage, rubbish discarded residential household goods, and
special and extra hauls as defined below in subsections (a)(1), (2), (3) and
(4).
      (1)   "Garbage"; means all wastes of offal of fish, fowl, fruit or
vegetable or animal matter resulting from the preparation of food for human
consumption in residential homes, commercial restaurants and other food service
operations.
      (2)   "Rubbish"; means baskets, wood, rags, old clothing, leather,
crockery, ashes, and other similar items, but does not include discarded
household goods or construction/demolition debris such as refuse from repairs,
alteration or new construction of curbs, sidewalks, buildings, or yard wastes
such as branches, brush, leaves and grass clippings.
      (3)   “Discarded Household Goods"; means all discarded furniture,
springs/ mattresses/ stoves, heaters, water heaters, washers, dryers, and any
other appliance that does not include a refrigeration unit/ small scrap wood
(exceeding thirty-six inches in length), toys/ porcelain, carpeting (tied and
bundled in less than a three cubic feet per bundle), leather/ rubber items, and
any other product which cannot be contained in a standard toter or container.
      (4)   “Special/Extra Hauls"; means the Collector has been requested by
the City to provide service for a Customer which is beyond the basic scope of
this agreement, including returning to an address to collect waste which was
not placed at the curb correctly or by the appointed time.
   (b)   “Board of Health"; means the Board of Health of Logan County/ Ohio.
   (c)   “City"; means the City of Bellefontaine, wholly contained within the
Logan County Solid Waste District.
   (d)    “Co-Location"; means the Collector collects waste for disposal along
a route which includes customers who are not Bellefontaine customers. This
would include private subscribers and/or other governmental routes in close
proximity with Bellefontaine, and would be collected more efficiently in the
same routing. Compensation to the City for disposal of the non-Bellefontaine
customers would be based on customer base or bag sales, whichever best applies.
   (e)   “Collector”; means the person, firm or corporation awarded a contract
for the collection of solid waste and/or recyclables within the corporate
limits of the City of Bellefontaine, Ohio.
   (f)   “Compensation”; means funds the City of Bellefontaine will pay to the
Collector or Collectors monthly in an amount equal to the unit price bid as
shown on the Proposal Form multiplied by the number of residential customers
with regular collection services for solid waste and/or recycling, plus
documented, out-of-season toter removals and replacement, and reimbursable
toter repairs and/or replacements. Any penalties for non-compliance of the
Collector will be credited toward payment of each monthly invoice. In the case
where the penalties are more than the invoice, the remainder will be applied to
payment of the invoice in the next billing period.
   (g)   “Container"; means a regulation plastic bag in either of two sizes
with capacity of not more than thirty-two gallons or a capacity of not less
than fifteen gallons and a thickness of not less than 1.5 mils or a portable
container constructed of plastic/galvanized metal or aluminum, not less than
ten gallons nor more than ninety gallons. In no case shall the container and
its contents exceed a weight of fifty pounds. Each container shall be provided
on the outside with two handles by which it may be lifted to be emptied and
shall be of watertight construction with a watertight lid or cover that shall
be equipped with a handle and shall be in place on the container except when
necessarily removed in the use of the container. Said regulation plastic bag
shall be further identified and known as a "Pay as You Throw" bag.
“Container”; includes:
      (1)   Subscription toters available in a 90-95 gallon (high volume) size.
Every toter will be fitted with a hinged lid. The containers provided by the
Collector shall be selected to remain attractive and durable throughout the
subscription term with reasonable consideration for normal wear and tear; and
      (2)   Prepaid (Bellefontaine “Pay-As-You-Throw”) plastic bags in either
of two sizes with capacity of not more than thirty-two gallons; or a capacity
of not more than fifteen gallons; and
      (3)   Any other program allowable customer container(s) with the City-
issued sticker(s), authorizing use and denoting payment for the container(s) to
be collected.
   In no case shall the container and its contents exceed a weight of fifty
pounds. Each container shall be provided on the outside with two handles by
which it may be lifted to be emptied and shall be of watertight construction
with a watertight lid or cover that shall be equipped with a handle and shall
be in place on the container except when necessarily removed in the use of the
container. Said regulations plastic bag shall be further identified and known
as a “Pay as You Throw” bag.
   (h)    "Customer"; means the person, firm, firm or organization receiving
service as further defined below.
      (1)   "Residential Customer"; means a householder, owner, and/or
occupants of either a single-family dwelling unit or a double-family residence
or triplex-family residence who receives solid waste recycling collection
service.
      (2)   "Commercial Customer"; means any person, firm, organization, or
corporation that owns or operates any store, restaurant, industry, institution,
office, multi-family dwelling unit, including all responsible persons of the
premises where solid waste is created and receives solid waste collection
service. The definition of Commercial Customer may change from time to time at
the City’s sole discretion. Reasonable notice will be provided to the
Collector. Commercial Recycling in not part of the Commercial Franchise.
   (i)    "Franchise Fee"; means an assigned percentage of the subscribed rate
designated by the City of Bellefontaine charged to all Commercial Customers
billed by the Collector to the customer for receiving service within the City
of Bellefontaine.
   (j)    "Handpick Customers"; means those customers who, due to restrictions
of the collection site availability where the pickup is provided, cannot be
serviced under the Commercial program as provided by the Collector.
   (k)    "Infirm, Temporary or Permanently Disabled Customers"; means a
customer who is eligible for enhanced service as a result of being unable to
lift twenty (20) pounds, and living alone or with other disabled people.
Generally speaking, a disabled customer is confined to a wheelchair or is
otherwise sufficiently immobilized to be unable to place a recycling bin or
container at the curb without assistance.
   (l)   "Landfill"; means Cherokee Run Landfill, Bellefontaine, Ohio.
   (m)   "MFDU"; means a Multi-Family Dwelling Unit, the grouping together of
four or more residential units under a common roof or sharing a common property
and shall constitute a commercial customer when all units within the commercial
property are invoiced and services are charged to the property holder. The
exception to private arrangements for commercial solid waste services, the City
may, at its sole discretion, arrange, invoice and pay for the appropriate level
of services for MFDUs.
   (n)   "MRF"; means Logan County Material Recovery Facility, Bellefontaine,
Ohio.
   (o)   "Recycling Bin"; means the issued regulation container(s) provided to
the service address for recycling services. The recycling bin(s) shall only be
used for these purposes. There is a maximum of two recycling bins provided for
each service address. Additional recycling may be placed in an appropriately
stickered plastic container or can be taken directly to the Logan County
Material Recovery Facility, "MRF" drop-off site. The recycling bin(s) are
considered the property of the City of Bellefontaine and are to remain with the
service address. Removal of the recycling bins from the service address is a
violation of City Ordinance and subject to punishment under City Ordinance and
Law including restitution of the cost of the bin(s).
   (p)    "Recycling Services"; means collecting weekly from each residential
customer recyclable items separated by the customers and placed in recycling
bins provided by the City. Recyclable items include glass food and beverage
containers, #1 and #2 plastic containers, Cardboard cut to fit in the recycling
bin, newspapers, magazines, junk mail, craft paper, office paper, aluminum
beverage containers, aluminum sheet, bi-metal cans, household batteries
isolated and contained in a clear plastic bag, and other items that from time
to time shall be recyclable from households and acceptable at receiving
recycling centers. The Collector will not be required to pickup recycling
containers when contaminants are obvious, found and present.
   (q)    "SFDU"; means a Single Family Dwelling Unit, including duplexes and
triplexes, except when the dwellings conform to the definition of "Multi Family
Dwelling Unit".
   (r)   "Seasonal Suspension"; means a residential customer who vacates their
property entirely for a minimum of one full calendar month. The residential
customer will be responsible for the safe-keeping and non-use of their
container while the property is vacant. Vacancy will be confirmed by verifying
that water consumption at the property address is less than three hundred (300)
gallons monthly during the suspension period and or by an inspection performed
by a representative of the City on a collection day for the service address of
the property. The customer is responsible to notify the Utility Office when
they have returned to the property to resume service collection. Violations
will result in penalties for the time the property was reported to be vacant
and for the replacement cost of any container if reported lost or missing.
Charges are not pro-rated during a month, and occupancy for any part of a month
constitutes occupancy for the entire month for billing purposes.
   
   (s)   "Utility Office"; means the City of Bellefontaine Department of Public
Utilities Office.
(Ord. 21-29. Passed 6-8-21.)
 
951.02 AUTHORITY OF SERVICE-SAFETY DIRECTOR.
   The Service-Safety Director is hereby authorized and directed to manage and
control the (Garbage and Refuse Collection Service) in a safe, economical and
efficient manner. Whenever the term Service-Safety Director is used in this
chapter it shall refer to and designate the individual currently serving in
that position or to his duly authorized representative acting in a supervisory
capacity.
(Ord. 21-29. Passed 6-8-21.)
 
951.03 BYLAWS AND REGULATIONS.
   The Service-Safety Director hereby is authorized and directed to make such
bylaws and regulations for the safe, economical and efficient management and
protection of the Garbage and Refuse Collection Service for the collection and
removal of garbage and rubbish, and for the construction of additions and
improvements for the Collection Service Program. Such bylaws and regulations
shall have the same force and effect as ordinances when not repugnant thereto
nor to the Constitution of laws of the State.
(Ord. 21-29. Passed 6-8-21.)
 
951.04 GARBAGE AND RUBBISH COLLECTION DEPARTMENT FUND.
   The funds received for the collection and removal of garbage and rubbish
shall be deposited with the City Treasurer and moneys so deposited shall be
kept in a separate and distinct fund to be known as the Garbage and Refuse
Fund.
(Ord. 21-29. Passed 6-8-21.)
 
951.05 USE OF MONEYS.
   Funds received from the Garbage and Refuse Fund shall be used for the
payment of the costs and expenses of the management, administration,
maintenance, operation, collection and landfill expense and supplies and any
surplus in the Garbage and Refuse Fund shall be used for the improvement of the
program including education and auditing expense.
(Ord. 21-29. Passed 6-8-21.)
 
951.06 USE AND LOCATION OF CONTAINERS.
   Residential and or Small Quantity Generator customers of any solid waste
collection service are required to place all garbage and rubbish with approved
containers, including pay as you throw bags, at the side of the public street
on which the residence is located for pick-up service prior to 6:00 a.m. on the
regular collection day, and such customers shall remove all garbage and rubbish
containers from the street side in front of or at the side of their residence
by the end of the regular collection day so that such garbage and rubbish
containers are not visible at the street side in front of or at the side of
such customer’s residence for more than the regular collection day. Residential
customers or residences and Small Quantity Generator customers that do not
front on a public street and commercial customers shall be permitted to place
containers at alley side or another location as may be approved by the Service-
Safety Director. Trash not properly containerized in approved tagged containers
or pay as you throw bags, will not be collected.
(Ord. 21-29. Passed 6-8-21.)
 
951.07 SANITATION OF CANS.
   All persons having a garbage can or cans for the collection of garbage and
rubbish shall at all times keep such can or cans in a clean and sanitary
condition. All garbage is to be placed in bags and contain no health hazardous
items. Broken glass, sharp objects or other items that present a hazard need to
be double bagged before being placed into the container. Health hazard items
such as needles and syringes must be disposed of in the properly marked
containers.
(Ord. 12-33. Passed 8-28-12.)
 
951.08 DRAINING AND WRAPPING GARBAGE; CONTAINERS.
   Garbage shall be drained of all liquid and wrapped sufficiently to keep each
package of garbage in a dry condition. The same container may be used for both
garbage and rubbish.
(Ord. 87-76. Passed 12-22-87.)
 
951.09 BOXES, PAPER AND TREE TRIMMINGS. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
951.09 was repealed by Ordinance 97-65, passed September 23, 1997.
 
951.10 DISCARDED HOUSEHOLD GOODS.
   Discarded household goods will require the purchase of bulky item tag(s)
prior to the item(s) set out for collection. The tags will need to be displayed
on the items for collection by the City of Bellefontaine Street Department and
will need to be set out prior to 7:00 a.m. for pickup on designated days weekly
authorized by the Service Safety Director. These items are not to be set at the
curb more than one day prior to the specified collection day.
(Ord. 21-29. Passed 6-8-21.)
 
951.11 RESIDENTIAL RATES.
   (a)    Residential and Small Quantity Generator subscribers to the City
Garbage and Refuse Collection service shall pay a basic collection and
processing service fee of nine dollars ($9.00) per month per household/
generator unit; payable in advance, which does not include disposal charges but
which includes collection of solid waste and recyclable materials as well as
recyclable material processing and marketing costs. Each such residential and
small quantity generator subscriber to said City garbage and refuse collection
service shall in addition to the above stated monthly fee pay a disposal
service fee as follows:
      (1)    $1.50 for each 32 gallon Bellefontaine City refuse blue bag (Pay
As You Throw Bag)
      (2)    $ .75 for each 15 gallon Bellefontaine City refuse blue bag (Pay
As You Throw Bag)
      (3)    $7.00 for each trash container 45 gallons or less in capacity
      (4)    $15.00 for each trash container greater than or equal to 46
gallons and less than 90 gallons in capacity
      (5)    $19.00 for each trash container/toter 90/95 gallons in capacity
that is leased.
   (b)   There are to be only two container(s) assigned to each Residential or
Small Quantity Generator property address or unit. Beginning February 1, 2021,
toters that are leased will require a refundable deposit to be paid upon
selection of this refuse option in advance in the amount of thirty dollars
($30.00). This deposit will be held on account until verification that the
toter has been secured at the termination of this refuse option. If the refuse
option is changed by the customer from the toter to a different level of
service, the deposit will be applied to the billed utility account.
      (1)   $7.50 for each bulky item for small and medium sized discarded
household good(s) that is less than one cubic yard in size and up to 50 pounds
in weight. Carpet to be collected must be cut no larger than four feet in
width, rolled and tied, and paid for in the amount of $7.50 per roll.
      (2)   $15.00 for each bulky item for larger sized discarded household
good(s) that is no larger than four cubic yards in size and up to 250 pounds in
weight.
   (c)    Commercial, Industrial and Residential customers that require roll-
off container service and pickup of construction and demolition debris from
repairs, demolition or new construction have the right to contract for this
service with any qualified construction and demolition debris hauler after
first notifying the Office of the Service Safety Director.
   (d)    Certain Commercial customers that are classified as " Handpick"
customers by the Service Safety Director due to restrictions of the collection
site that cannot be serviced under the normal Commercial Program as provided by
the refuse hauler will be billed by the Collector to the City of Bellefontaine
for further payment due by the customer. These charges will be established
based upon the container type and frequency of pickup collection; in addition
the Franchise Fee will also be applied to the Commercial customer's utility
account.
   (e)    The City of Bellefontaine will maintain records on Commercial
customers who receive refuse collection service as provided by the Collector.
When it is found that there is no record of refuse collection available for a
Commercial customer address, the City of Bellefontaine will require the
completion of a "Certification of Service" which will allow for shared
container service. (Ord. 21-29. Passed 6-8-21.)
951.12 COMMERCIAL RATE.
   (a)   All Commercial Customers shall be provided an appropriate level of
service by the authorized Collector for the City of Bellefontaine. The
Collector shall be responsible for all invoicing and collections from
Commercial Customers. The Collector shall provide to the City of Bellefontaine
a schedule of compensations required for collecting all common sizes of
containers and the frequency of collection. In addition, the Collector will
charge a six percent (6%) franchise fee monthly to each commercial customer
billed which will be payable within the following month after collection and
deposited into the Garbage and Refuse Fund of the City of Bellefontaine for
refuse service operations within the City of Bellefontaine. The Collector may
not deviate from the Commercial Customer Compensation matrix unless authorized
in writing by the Service Safety Director.
   (b)   Industrial and commercial customers that generate special waste
materials have the right to contract with any waste hauler or recycler for
their special disposal needs after obtaining written approval from the Service-
Safety Director. Commercial customers that operate in multiple locations that
hold corporate refuse contracts will be authorized to contract only with the
appointed hauler when required by the Service Safety Director.
   (c)   Residents, commercial and industrial customers that require roll-off
container service and pickup of construction and demolition debris from
repairs, demolition or new construction have the right to contract for this
service with any qualified construction and demolition debris hauler.
   (d)   Certain commercial customers that are classified as “handpick”
customers by Service Safety Director due to restrictions of the site where
pickup is provided and can not be serviced under the Commercial Program as
provided by the refuse hauler. These customers will be billed to the City by
the refuse hauler at the appropriate rate established for the container type
used. This charge will then be passed on to the customer receiving this service
with an additional six percent (6%) franchise fee. This fee will be included
with the authorized refuse service fee and charged monthly to the commercial
customer’s utility account billing.
   (e)   Commercial Recycling is not part of the contracted franchise services.
(Ord. 21-29. Passed 6-8-21.)
951.13 RESPONSIBILITY OF OWNERS AND TENANTS.
   (a)    All Residential or Commercial Customers shall only place solid waste
and recyclables in regulation containers. All solid waste must be placed in
trash bags with no loose, unsecured garbage.
   (b)    All Residential or Commercial Customers shall subscribe for garbage
and rubbish pickup collection service with the City of Bellefontaine. In
Double-Family, Triplex-Family and Multi-Family units or residences where the
Landlord is charged by the Department of Public Utilities for the water and
sewer service; that Landlord shall also be responsible for subscribing to and
for the payment of the garbage and rubbish collection service options
appropriate for those tenants residing in those units.
      
   (c)    All Residential Customers and Small Quantity Generators shall be
billed for refuse collection in conjunction with their regular utility
billings.
   (d)    Every residential address that is occupied will be held accountable
for the safe keeping of their container(s) and recycling bin(s). All recycling
bin(s) are to remain with the service address and are not considered property
of the subscribing customer. Recycling bins that have been removed from the
property is considered theft and subject to reimbursement and/or penalties as
provided for under Section
951.99.
   (e)    All trash/refuse containers need to be placed at the curb for
collection prior to 6:00 a.m. of their collection day and shall have the lid
fully seated on the container. Any additional refuse will need to be contained
in the regulation “Pay As You Throw” refuse bags. Recycling collection will be
the same pick-up day, set out for collection by 6:00 a.m. All recyclables need
to be sorted paper/fiber from metal/glass containers in different bins or
separated in the bin, top and bottom with no plastic bags and shall be set out
next to the trash containers. If it is found that the refuse or recycling was
missed in collection due to the fact it was not set out by 6:00 a.m. contracted
start time; the refuse/recycling will not be picked up until the following week
collection day and there will be no credit of service amount. If it is for
health and safety reasons that the refuse would still need to be picked up for
collection, there will be an additional fee charged for this service as stated
in the current Collector’s Contract Agreement.
   (f)    All trash must be containerized in regulation size, stickered
containers assigned to the address where the garbage and rubbish was generated.
All non-compliance will be considered theft of service for the purpose of
compensation and prosecution.
   (g)    If a container needs to be replaced due to normal wear, damage, is
missing or an exchange to a different size or option, the customer will need to
contact the Department of Public Utilities in order to notify the City of any
container option change and to receive the appropriate sticker authorization.
   (h)    Customer questions and quality complaints on refuse collection need
to be directed to the City of Bellefontaine Department of Public Utilities to
be resolved.
   (i)    No person shall allow garbage, trash, rubbish or other refuse to
accumulate out-of-doors for more than one week at a time. Such matter shall be
placed out-of-doors only in regulation lidded containers or plastic bags
designed for such purpose. No person shall permit any fermented, putrifying or
odorous garbage and/or rubbish to exist upon any property owned, leased, rented
or controlled by him.
   (j)    Property owners or tenants who allow refuse to accumulate for longer
than seven days shall be notified by certified mail to remove such
accumulation. If such condition is not corrected within seven days of the
mailing of such notice, the offender shall be cited into Municipal Court for a
violation of this section.
   (k)    Commercial dumpsters will not be allowed at single-family residences
unless there is an approved Commercial business in operation at that service
address.
(Ord. 21-29. Passed 6-8-21.)
951.14 USE OF SERVICE BY NONSUBSCRIBERS.
   (a)    No subscriber to the City of Bellefontaine garbage and rubbish
collection service shall permit use of his garbage or rubbish container by any
nonsubscriber to such service.
   (b)    Residential customers who may also subscribe to Commercial service
for a container at another service address will still be required to pay the
basic service fee for their personal residence. (Ord. 12-33. Passed 8-28-12.)
951.15 PERMITS; FEES.
   (a)    No person shall remove, pick up or haul garbage or rubbish over or
through any of the streets, alleys or other public thoroughfares of the City
without a permit therefore issued by the City Service Safety Director.
   (b)    The Collector shall covenant and agree to comply with all laws,
ordinances and regulations, which are applicable to garbage and rubbish
collection and with any contract entered into with the City. (Ord. 12-33.
Passed 8-28-12.)
 
951.16 YARD WASTE.
   (a)   Yard waste means any grass clippings, mulch, leaves, sticks, twigs,
brush, branches, weeds, vegetable matter, and any other organic material
generated by the maintenance or care of yards, flower beds, gardens, lawns,
hedges, bushes, trees or the like.
   (b)   No person, firm or corporation shall place or cause to be placed for
collection, by any refuse collection contractor intending disposal at any
landfill, and yard waste generated in the City of Bellefontaine. (Ord. 21-29.
Passed 6-8-21.)
 
951.17 ANNUAL FREE PICK-UP.
   The Mayor and Service-Safety Director are authorized to provide and carry-
out a one time per year annual free pick-up of solid waste refuse to the
citizens of the City of Bellefontaine upon such terms and conditions as the
Service-Safety Director may specify, and will only be carried out, if in the
discretion of the Service-Safety Director, the City has the manpower and
finances to pay for said free solid waste refuse pickup. The rates published in
this chapter shall not apply to this one time annual pick-up as may be provided
for herein.
(Ord. 07-27. Passed 6-12-07.)
 
951.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day on which a violation shall
occur or continue shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense.
(Ord. 87-76. Passed 12-22-87.)

Municipal Airport
953.01   Use of facilities; permit required.

953.03   Permit revocation.

CROSS REFERENCES
Airport - see Ohio R. C. Ch. 4563
Airports and temporary fields - see OAC Ch. 5501:1-1
 
953.01 USE OF FACILITIES; PERMIT REQUIRED.
   The Service-Safety Director is hereby authorized and directed to issue
permits for individuals to use hangar and tie-down facilities at the Municipal
Airport in furtherance of the public purpose of the operation of such airport.
No person shall use such facilities without first obtaining such a permit.
(Ord. 3517. Passed 2-24-71.)
 
953.02 PERMIT APPLICATION.
   Facilities described in Section
953.01 shall be available to any person, firm, corporation, association or any
other organization of good business and moral character, who makes a sworn
application in writing on a form to be furnished by the Service-Safety
Director, which shall give the following information:
   (a)   The name and description of the applicant.
   (b)   The address and telephone number of the applicant.
   (c)   The applicant's place of employment and the nature of his business.
   (d)   The nature and number of the applicant's flying license.
   (e)   A description of the plane to be stored.
      (Ord. 3517. Passed 2-24-71.)
 
953.03 PERMIT REVOCATION.
   Permits issued under this chapter may be revoked by the Service-Safety
Director for any of the following causes:
   (a)   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
application for the permit.
   (b)   Conviction of any crime involving moral turpitude.
   (c)   Utilizing the facilities of the Airport in an unlawful manner or in
such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace
to the health, safety or general welfare of the public.
      (Ord. 3517. Passed 2-24-71.)
 
953.04 RATES.

   (b)   Effective October 1, 2021:
 
Hanger 7-25 $2,000
(Ord. 21-66. Passed 9-28-21.)
 
953.05 ADMINISTRATION BY FIXED BASE OPERATOR.
   The duly qualified and acting Service-Safety Director of the City may
delegate any of the operations, authorizations and procedures heretofore within
this chapter authorized to be performed by the Service-Safety Director to the
fixed base operator of such Airport who is then under contract with the City
for the operation of the same.
(Ord. 91-26. Passed 4-9-91.)
 
953.06 MINIMUM STANDARDS FOR AERONAUTICAL ACTIVITY.
   The minimum standards for aeronautical activity at the new Bellefontaine
Regional Airport as are specifically described on the Exhibit “A” attached to
Ordinance 02-52, incorporated herein by reference, the same as if fully
rewritten herein, are hereby adopted and approved for the new Bellefontaine
Regional Airport.
(Ord. 02-52. Passed 7-9-02.)

953
 
RULES AND REGULATIONS
AUTHORITY: The Airport Manager shall at all times have authority to take such
action as may be necessary to safeguard all persons in attendance at the
Airport.
 
SCOPE: All persons on any part of the property comprising the Airport, shall be
governed by the regulations prescribed herein and instructions of the Manager
relative to the use of any part of the property comprising the Airport. Theses
regulations are subject to amendment.
 
PENALTIES: The Airport Manager may remove or evict from the Airport premises
any persons who knowingly or willfully violates any rule or regulation
prescribed herein, or any rule or regulation of the Federal Aviation
Administration or the State of Ohio, and may deny the use of the Airport and
its facilities to any such person if it is determined that such denial is in
the public interest.
 
AIRPORT LIABILITY: The City, its agents or employees shall not be liable for
loss, damage or injury to persons or property arising from accident, incident,
or mishap of any nature whatsoever and/or from any cause whatsoever to any
individual, aircraft, or property, occurring on the Airport or in the use of
any of the Airport.
 
CONDITIONS: The permission granted by the City of Bellefontaine, to use the
said Airport and its facilities, shall be at all time conditioned upon the
assumption of full responsibility therefore, by every person exercising or
taking advantage of such permission. It shall be a further condition thereof
that each person, as a consideration for the use of said Airport and its
facilities, shall at all times, release, hold harmless, and indemnify the City
of Bellefontaine and/or its agents and employees from and against any and all
responsibility, liability, loss or damage resulting to any such person, or
caused by or on his behalf, and incident to the manner in which the Airport is
operated, constructed, maintained, or served from within or without. The use of
said Airport by any person for any purpose, or the paying of any fees
therefore, or the operation of aircraft thereon, shall be in itself an
acknowledgment that such persons accept such privileges on the conditions
herein set forth. All pilots, commercial operators, or other person shall use
the Bellefontaine Regional Airport at their own risk, and in case of failure of
any municipally owned equipment, the City of Bellefontaine will not assume the
responsibility.
 
954.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   "CITY" means the City of Bellefontaine, Ohio.
   (b)   "AIRPORT" means Bellefontaine Regional Airport
   (c)   "DIRECTOR OF AVIATION" means the person with the overall
responsibility for the operation and management of all City owned Airport(s),
or his duly authorized representative. The City Service-Safety Director is
recognized as the Director of Aviation.
   (d)   "AIRPORT MANAGER" means the person responsible for its operation and
management of the Airport or his duly authorized representative. The Airport's
FBO is recognized as the Airport Manager.
   (e)   "PERSON" means an individual, firm, partnership, corporation,
association, joint stock association, or political body and includes any trust
receiver agency assigned or similar representative thereof.
   (f)    "EMPLOYEE" means any individual employed on the Airport.
   (g)    "AIRCRAFT" means any and all machines or contrivances used for
navigation of flight in air or space.
   (h)   "MOTOR VEHICLE" means automobiles, trucks, buses, motorcycles, tugs
and any other devices by which person or property may be transported on land.
   (i)   "AIRCRAFT OPERATOR" means any person engaged in the operation of
aircraft either as the owner or lessor/lessee of aircraft, for business or
pleasure.
   (j)   "RESTRICTED AREA" means any area in the Airport not open to the
general public.
   (k)   "AIR OPERATIONS AREA" means all runways, taxiways or ramps;
paved or sod, which support the movement or parking of aircraft.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.02 GENERAL RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Operation of Aircraft: No person shall navigate any aircraft, land
upon, fly same from, service, maintain, repair any aircraft, or conduct any
aircraft operations on or from the Airport otherwise than in conformity with
current, or as subsequently revised or amended, Federal Aviation Administration
and Civil Aeronautics Board rules and any State of Ohio rules and regulations
governing aircraft not in conflict with Federal rules and regulations.
   (b)   FAA Air Traffic Rules: The Air Traffic Rules as established by the
Federal Aviation Administration or its successors and currently in effect, or
as subsequently revised or amended, are hereby adopted by reference and made a
part of these rules as fully as if the same and each and all of them were set
forth herein.
   (c)   Roads, Walks, Ramps, Taxiways, Runways, Land: No persons shall use the
roads, walks, ramps, taxiways, runways or land in such a manner as to obstruct
or interfere with their proper use.
   (d)   Construction, Alterations Etc.: No person shall do any construction,
alterations, work or electrical wiring in or to any existing hangar or building
on the Airport without first securing written authorization from the Airport
Manager. Violators will be required to remove such work at their own expense.
   (e)   Advertisements: No person shall post, distribute or display signs,
advertisements, circulars, printed or written material on the Airport without
authorization from the Airport Manager.
   (f)   Soliciting: No person shall solicit fares, alms or funds for any
purpose on the Airport without written authorization from the Airport Manager.
   (g)   Reporting Accidents/Incidents: All accidents/incidents in which a
motor vehicle, aircraft, person or employee becomes involved shall be reported
to the Airport Manager immediately or within a reasonable length of time
following such occurrence.
   (h)   Littering: No person shall throw, cast, dump, place, deposit, cause to
be thrown, cast dumped, placed or deposited, garbage, waste, roughage, refuse,
junk, trash paper, dirt, gravel, sand or any other material whatsoever on
Airport Property or allow said items to remain on Airport Property without
first obtaining written authorization from the Airport Manager.
   (i)   Hunting:  No hunting or trapping shall be permitted on Airport
Property.
   (j)   Dogs and Pets: Dogs or other animals brought upon Airport Property
must be restrained by a leash or confined in such a manner as to be under
control at all times.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.03 MOTOR VEHICLES AND MOBILE EQUIPMENT.
   (a)   Operations: No person shall operate any motor vehicle on the Airport
except in accordance with the rules prescribed by the Airport Manager and the
motor vehicle laws of the State of Ohio and the ordinances of the City of
Bellefontadne.
   (b)   Ramps and Aprons:  No person shall park any motor vehicle or mobile
equipment on the ramp areas.
   (c)   Runways and Taxiways: No person shall operate any motor vehicle or
mobile equipment on the runways or taxiways without permission from the Airport
Manager. The Airport Manager may require flags on vehicles operating on the
runways and taxiways. Such flags shall comply with Federal Aviation
Administration regulations.
   (d)   Speed Limits on the Ramps: Maximum speed limit on the ramps shall be
15 miles per hour. Where conditions require, the maximum speed shall be
reduced. All equipment being operated near aircraft shall be limited to a speed
of not more than 5 miles per hour.
   (e)   Speed Limits on the Roadways: Vehicles operating on the Airport
roadways shall not exceed posted speed limits.
   (f)   Parking: 
      (1)   No person shall park a motor vehicle for any purpose on the Airport
other than in the areas specifically established for parking and in the manner
prescribed by signs, lines or other means. No person shall park a motor vehicle
in a manner as to obstruct roadways or fire lanes. The Airport Manager may make
exceptions for client parking.
      (2)   No vehicle shall be left abandoned, unlicensed or with expired
license plates, nor shall any vehicle remain parked in excess or 24 hours
except in conjunction with the operator's air travel from the Airport.
      (3)   All employees of firms engaged in business at the Airport shall
park only in areas designated for employee parking. It is the responsibility of
the employer to regulate his/her employee parking area to assure convenient
parking is available to their customers and the customers of the Airport.
Tenants of T-Hangars should park their vehicles so as to not impede vehicle or
aircraft traffic.
      (4)   The Manager shall have the authority to tow, or otherwise move,
motor vehicles which are parked on the Airport in violation of the regulations
of the Airport, at the operator's expense and without liability for damage
which may result in the course of such moving.
   (g)   Any cater or trailer pulled by a tractor, truck or other motorized
vehicle must have either tail lights, red reflectors or red reflecting tape on
the side and rear.
   (h)   All vehicles operating on the Airport between the hours of sunset and
sunrise shall have fully operating headlights and taillights.
   (i)   Pedestrians and aircraft shall at all times have the right-of-way over
vehicular traffic. All vehicles shall pass to the rear of the taxing aircraft.
   (j)   No persons operating a motor vehicle on the Airport shall fail to give
proper signals or fail to observe the directions or posted traffic signs.
   (k)   No person under the influence of liquor or narcotic drugs shall
operate a motor vehicle or aircraft on the Airport.
   (l)   When an accident occurs involving two moving vehicles or a moving
vehicle and a fixed object, the accident shall be reported to the Airport
Manager or the Director of Aviation immediately, or as soon as possible
thereafter.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.04 AIRCRAFT OPERATIONS.
   (a)   Aircraft Storage and Repair: Aircraft shall be stored or parked and
repairs made in spaces designated for this purpose.
   (b)   Securing of Unattended Aircraft: No aircraft shall be left unattended
on Airport Property unless properly secured or within a hangar. Owners of such
aircraft shall be held responsible for any damage resulting from failure to
comply with this rule.
   (c)   Parking of Aircraft: No aircraft shall be parked or left unattended
within 50 feet of the edge of any taxiway nor within 175 feet of any runway.
Aircraft shall be parked only in areas designated for such purpose, and only
during such periods as may be established by the Director of Aviation.
   (d)   Clearance: The Airport Manager may delay or restrict any flight or
other operations at the Airport for any justifiable reason.
   (e)   Closing Field: In the event the Airport Manager or a designated
Director of Aviation representative believes conditions of the Airport or any
part of the Airport to be unsafe for landing or take-offs, its shall be within
his authority to close the entire Airport or any portion thereof. A NOTAM shall
be filed with the FAA Flight Service Station. The same procedure will be
followed when the field is again usable.
   (f)   Aircraft Accident: If an accident occurs on, or adjacent to a runway,
that runway shall immediately close and not reopen for flight operations until
an authorized Director of Aviation representative has completed a runway
inspection and declared the area safe for resumption of operations.
   (g)   Disabled Aircraft: Aircraft owners, their agent(s) or pilot shall be
responsible for the prompt removal of disabled aircraft and part thereof unless
required or directed to delay such action pending an investigation of an
accident.
   (h)   Lighting Facility Damage: Any person damaging any light or fixture by
means of contact with aircraft or vehicle shall report such damage to the
Airport Manager's office immediately and shall be fully responsible for any
costs required to repair or replace the damaged facility.
   (i)   Taxiing Rules:
      (1)   No aircraft shall be operated in a careless or reckless manner or
taxied except at a safe and reasonable speed.
      (2)   Aircraft shall be taxied in accordance with prescribed taxiing
patterns.
      (3)   No person who is under the influence of alcohol or any other drugs
shall start or run an engine in any aircraft.
      (4)   Starting, Running and Warming of Engines: No aircraft engine shall
be started or run unless a competent operator shall be attending the controls.
Chocks shall always be placed in front of the main landing wheels before
starting the engine unless the aircraft is equipped with adequate locking
brakes. Aircraft shall be started and warmed up only in areas designated for
such purposes. Aircraft engines shall not be operated in such a position that
hangars, shops or other buildings, or spectators or automobiles or other
aircraft shall be damaged or injured thereby.
      (5)   Taxiing into or out of Hangars: Aircraft shall not be taxied into
or out of hangars under any circumstances.
      (6)   Operating Aircraft Under Directions: Each person operating an
aircraft on Airport Property shall comply with the rules, regulations and
directions of the FAA and Bellefontaine Regional Airport.
      (7)   Exhaust Blast: No person may start or taxi any aircraft on the
Airport in a place where the exhaust blast is likely to cause injury to persons
or property. If the aircraft cannot be taxied without violating this paragraph,
the operator must have it towed.
      (8)   Rotorcraft: No person shall move a rotorcraft at a place on the
Airport while its rotors are turning unless there is a clear area of at least
25 feet from the outer tip of each rotor.
   (j)   Aircraft Traffic Regulations:
      (1)   Unless otherwise advised, aircraft will enter the traffic pattern
at an altitude of 2,100 feet M.S.L. and fly a standard left hand rectangular
pattern for all runways.
      (2)   In all cases, take-offs and landings over populated areas will be
kept to a minimum in the interest of public safety, convenience and noise
abatement.
      (3)   Prior authorization by the Airport Manager is required before
balloons, airships, motorless aircraft or aircraft with total weight in excess
of 75,000 pounds land or takes off.
      (4)   It is recognized that emergencies, or other abnormal conditions,
may require deviation from the above procedures.
         (Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.05 AIRCRAFT FUELING AND DEFUELING.
   (a)   Prohibited While Running Engine: No Aircraft shall be fueled or
drained of fuel while the engine or engines are running or while such aircraft
is in a hangar or enclosed space. All fueling to take place only in areas
designated by the Airport Manager.
   (b)   Bounding of Electrical Potential Required: During fueling, the
aircraft and the fuel dispensing apparatus shall both be bounded to a point or
points of zero electrical potential.
   (c)   Smoking: No person shall smoke within 100 ft. of an aircraft being
fueled or defueled.
   (d)   Only Essential Personnel Permitted: Only personnel engaged in the
fueling, maintenance, and operation of an aircraft shall be permitted within
fifty feet of fuel tanks or such aircraft during any such operation.
   (e)   Static Spark Material Prohibited: No person shall use any material
during fueling or draining of fuel from aircraft which is likely to cause a
static discharge.
   (f)   Adequate Fire Extinguishers:  Adequate fire extinguishers shall be
within ready reach of personnel engaged in fueling and draining operations.
   (g)   Maintenance of Equipment: Fueling hoses and draining equipment shall
be maintained in a safe, sound and non-leaking condition.
   (h)   Grounding Device:  All hoses, funnels and appurtenances used in
fueling and draining operations shall be equipped with a grounding device to
prevent ignition.
   (i)   Fueling and Draining: The fueling and draining of aircraft shall be
conducted at least 50 feet from any hangar or other building. Persons engaged
in the fueling and drainage of aircraft shall exercise care to prevent overflow
of fuel. Persons responsible will take proper measures to clean up volatile
liquids which are spilled.
   (j)   Spilling of Contaminants: No fuel, oil, dope, paint, solvent or acid
shall be disposed of or dumped in drains, on the ramp areas, catch basins,
ditches or elsewhere on the Airport. In case of any accidental or unauthorized
spillage of gasoline, jet fuel or oil, the company, person or persons
responsible for such spillage must report this information to Airport Manager,
the Director of Aviation, and the State of Ohio Environmental Protection Agency
(EPA), immediately or as soon as possible after each occurrence.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.06 FIRE HAZARDS.
   (a)   Smoking: No person shall smoke on the Apron in the hangars, hangar
aprons, or in any other area on the Airport in violation of posted "No Smoking"
signs, and in no case at a distance less than 30 feet from any aircraft or
storage area for flammable materials.
   (b)   Open Flame Operations: No person shall conduct any open flame
operations in any hangar or part thereof unless specifically authorized.
   (c)   Storage: No person shall store or stock material or equipment in such
manner as to constitute a fire hazard.
   (d)   Storage of Flammable Material: No person shall keep, store or discard
any flammable liquids, gases, signal flares or other similar material in the
hangars or in any other building on the Airport. Small quantities of cleaning
solvents and lubricating oil are permitted for personal use only.
   (e)   Waste: Lessees of hangars shall provide suitable metal receptacles
with self- closing covers for the storage of oily wastes, rags and other
rubbish. All such wastes shall be removed from the Airport by the Lessee.
   (f)    Floor Care: All Lessees on the Airport shall keep the floors of the
hangers and hanger apron pits, and areas adjacent thereto leased by the
respective party, free and clear of oil, grease, rubbish and other flammable
material.
   (g)   Painting: The painting processes shall be conducted only in designated
and properly designed fireproofed and ventilated rooms or buildings in which
all illumination, wiring, heating, ventilation equipment, switches, outlets,
and fixtures shall be spark proofed.
   (h)   Fire Equipment:  No person shall remove or cause to be removed from
its holder, container, reel, or bracket, any equipment or device used in fire
prevention, except in case of emergency or fire. In any event, such equipment
shall not be taken for any use other than that for which it is intended.
   (i)   Obstructions: All fire doors, hangar doors, sprinkler risers, fire
boxes, fire hydrants and pits, hose boxes, and all fire fighting apparatus
shall be kept clear of obstructions at all times.
   (j)   Elimination of Fire Hazards: When the Director of Aviation has in
writing notified or requested any Lessee, tenant or other person(s) on the
Airport to correct, or eliminate any fire hazard, such Lessee, tenant, or other
person(s) shall be responsible for correcting or eliminating such hazard in the
manner and within the time prescribed in the written notification or request
received by them.
   (k)   Parking of Fuel Trucks:  No fuel truck shall be parked or left
unattended within 25 feet of any building on the Airport Property.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.07 PUBLIC AND TENANT USE.
   (a)   Disorderly Conduct: No person shall be or become intoxicated, commit
any disorderly, obscene or indecent act or commit any act of nuisance, or
conduct or engage in any form of criminal activity on the Airport.
   (b)   Sanitation: No person shall dispose of garbage, papers, refuse or
other material on the Airport except in the receptacles provided for that
purpose; nor use a comfort station other than in a clean and sanitary manner.
   (c)   Preservation of Property: No person shall destroy, injure, deface or
disturb any building, sign, equipment, marker or other structure, trees,
flowers, lawn or other property, nor alter, make additions to or erect any
buildings or signs or make any excavations; nor willfully abandon any personal
property.
   (d)   Interfering or Tampering with Aircraft:  No person shall interfere or
tamper with any aircraft, start the engine of any aircraft or use any aircraft
part, instrument or tool without the permission of the owner, or by specific
direction of the Airport Manager.
   (e)   Restricted Areas: No person shall enter upon the field area,
utilities, and service rooms or areas or other areas as may be designated
restricted, except:
      (1)   Persons assigned to duty therein;
      (2)   Persons authorized by the Airport Manager;
      (3)   Passengers under appropriate supervision, entering the apron for
the purpose of embarkation or debarkation.
   (f)   Emergency Response Force: In case of accident/incident involving an
aircraft on airport property, only authorized emergency response vehicles and/
or personnel are permitted on the airport operating areas. Spectators and other
unauthorized personnel are prohibited from entering the restricted area or
crash site areas. Well intended actions by unqualified persons could actually
impede or hinder qualified personnel from performing their duties. Violators
will be prosecuted under applicable local, state and/or federal law.
   (g)   Loitering and Refusal to Comply: No person shall loiter or loaf on any
part of the Airport in any building on the Airport; nor shall any person come
upon or use the Airport, except while enplaning or deplaning as a passenger on
an aircraft operating on the Airport, after such person has been denied the use
of the Airport by the Airport Manager. Any person who shall refuse to comply
with these rules and regulations after request by the Airport Manager, or other
authorized representative, shall be requested to leave the Airport, and in the
event of failure to leave the Airport, and in the event of failure to comply
with such request shall be regarded as a trespasser.
   (h)   Use of Shop Areas: All shops, garages, equipment and facilities are
for the conduct of the owner's or lessee's business and operations. No persons
other than employees of the owner or lessee shall make use of these facilities
or loiter on such premises without permission of the owner or lessee. This
section applies to all premises.
   (i)   Conduct of Business or Commercial Activity:
      (1)   Commercial use. No person shall use the Airport as a base or
terminal for the carrying on of passengers, freight, express or mail,
commercial aviation, or for student flying, communications, or other commercial
or private purpose of transportation without first securing written
authorization from the Director of Aviation and paying the fees and charges
prescribed for such privileges, the use of the Airport, its facilities, and for
services rendered.
      (2)   Concessions. No person shall engage in any commercial operation or
service, or solicit funds from the public on the Airport for any purpose or
post, distribute or display signs, advertisements, hand-bills, circulars,
printed or written matter at the Airport except with the written authorization
in the manner prescribed by the Airport Manager and upon payment of the rates
and charges prescribed or the rates specifically agreed upon by and between the
City and such person for such use.
      (3)   Tenant's Responsibility. Every company or organization operating at
the Airport shall maintain an up-to-date file containing the name, address and
telephone number of all employees, pilots and owners of aircraft based on its
premises. This information shall be available to the Airport Manager on
request.
   (j)   Open Flame Operations: No person shall conduct any open-flame
operations on the airport unless specifically authorized by the Airport
Manager.
   (k)   Smoking: No person shall smoke on the Airport apron, in any hangar or
shop, gasoline storage area, building, room or place where smoking is
specifically prohibited or within 100 feet of any fueling or defueling
operation.
   (l)   Trash Containers: No person shall keep uncovered trash containers. No
vehicle used for hauling trash, dirt or any other material shall be operated on
the Airport unless such vehicle is constructed so as to prevent the contents
thereof from dropping, sifting, leaking or otherwise escaping. Areas to be used
for trash or garbage containers shall be designated by the Airport Manager, and
no other areas shall be used. Such areas shall be kept clean and sanitary at
all times.
   (m)   Maintenance: All tenants shall maintain their leased property in a
condition of repair, cleanliness and general maintenance in a manner agreeable
to the Airport Manager, in accordance with their individual lease agreements
and free from all fire hazards.
   (n)   Fire Equipment: All tenants or lessees shall supply and maintain
adequate and readily accessible fire extinguishers approved by Fire
Underwriters for the particular hazard involved.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
LAND USE GUIDELINES
The City is fortunate to own a significant amount of property at the Airport.
This provides room for not only for runway extensions, but also for hangar
construction and aeronautical commercial development.
The Airport Master Plan proposed by R.W. Armstrong sets forth the parameters of
future Airport development and land use. The Airport Layout Plan is attached as
Exhibit A. The Terminal Area Plan is attached as Exhibit B.
Generally speaking, the areas contiguous to the existing apron and near the
Main Hangar/Terminal Building are to be reserved for aeronautical commercial
activity, such as, airplane leasing, flight training, aircraft repairs, charter
service and other airport support activities.
Current traffic and based counts far exceed both FAA and State forecast
information, and based upon user survey results, the trend for continued growth
at Bellefontaine Regional Airport should remain strong. This growth trend in
aircraft operations, when combined with the increased in size and speed of
aircraft using and expected to used the Airport, has been used to identify a
strategy of phased development, which will allow the Airport to expand
incrementally while simultaneously protecting against incompatible land uses in
the path of future development. Details of this strategy can be found in the
2006 Bellefontaine Regional Airport Master Plan Update.
954.08 PLANNING.
   (a)   One approach to land use management involves the use of existing
policies and development guidelines available through a number of different
planning processes. For airports, these occur at several levels. The various
levels of planning include airport system planning, regional and community
comprehensive planning, airport master planning, integrated multi-modal
planning, and capital improvement programs. Solutions to the land use issues
that arise in communities surrounding airports must be incorporated into the
airport and community planning and development process. The City can work
closely with the appropriate state agencies to insure optimal airport layout
and conformity with various laws and regulations.
   (b)   Integrating airport planning at the three different levels can aid in
the process of developing a compatible land use plan. The airport system plan,
regional and community comprehensive plans, and airport master plan can proceed
independently, but the value of each is increased when one provides input into
the other.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.09 OHIO AVIATION SYSTEM PLAN.
   (a)   Responding to the growth in aviation, the federal government enacted
the Airport and Airways Development Act of 1970 to assist state and local
authorities in the planning and development of airports of national interest.
The general intent of the act was that each state should have a plan for the
systematic development of such airports, with federal government participating
financially in the preparation of the plan as well as in subsequent facility
development.
   (b)   The Ohio Aviation System Plan (OASP) has been prepared and is updated
every five to seven years to guide decision making at the state and local
levels. System planning considers the local airport as part of a network of
airports which provides air transportation activities for a large area such as
a nation, state, or a region. The important factor in system planning is the
determination of the general location and function of airports to provide safe
and efficient service into the future.
   (c)   In addition, the OASP provides data on Ohio airports to the FAA for
use in evaluating possible inclusion in the National Plan of Integrated Airport
Systems (NPIAS). Inclusion in the NPIAS makes the state's airports eligible for
federal development assistance.
   (d)   Complimentary to the statewide system plan, reliever studies have been
carried out to develop more specific system plans for a number of the major
urban areas in Ohio.
   (e)   The Ohio Airport System consists of 110 public use airports, including
eight proposed new airports, and two proposed new heliports, for a total of 112
facilities. These facilities are owned by various counties, municipalities, a
township, and private individuals.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.10 COMPREHENSIVE PLANNING.
   (a)   Regional and Community comprehensive planning occur at the local
level. The City's comprehensive plan establishes policies for the development
and improvement of the community. Here the airport is considered not only in
terms of its impact on transportation, but also in terms of its effect on the
local economy, land use, and environment. The airport should be incorporated
into the total transportation plan to meet the community's needs. Especially
important in this respect is access to the airport by road, rail, and public
transportation, where appropriate.
   (b)   The primary purpose of the City's comprehensive plan with respect to
the local airport should be to support the efficient operation of the airport.
Within the land use element of the comprehensive plan, the future plan should
show the land area required for airport purposes and designate land uses for
surrounding properties that are compatible with airport operations. The general
location and extent of designated uses should be based on a forecast of demand
for various types of development and a consideration of the likely
characteristics of such development.
   (c)   Communities with comprehensive plans that contain an airport component
are more likely to be successful in achieving land uses compatible with the
local airport. The comprehensive plan provides a legal basis for airport land
uses and community consensus in support of the airport's existing and future
operations.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.11 AIRPORT MASTER PLANNING.
   (a)   Airport master planning means the level of planning relating directly
to airport facilities. The airport master plan includes an analysis of the
specific improvements necessary to provide the proper level of service for the
forecast demand.
   (b)   The airport master planning process should identify the impact of
airport operations on land use in the vicinity and recommend actions to
alleviate negative impacts. The master plan will also show the areas for which
fee simple land acquisitions and easements should be obtained. In fact,
Congress has required an airport sponsor requesting federal aid under the
Airport Improvement Program (AIP) to show the actions taken to restrict the use
of land adjacent to, or in the immediate vicinity of the airport, to activities
and purposes compatible with normal airport operations. In additions, the
sponsor must specify how this has been accomplished by providing information on
any zoning laws enacted or in force restricting the use of land adjacent to or
in the vicinity of the airport.
   (c)   The Airport Layout Plan (ALP) is the technical section of the master
plan depicting the specific development of the airport's facilities. Of the
seven required drawing, one solely depicts the noise contours associated with
airport use and the recommended development pattern for land surrounding the
airport.
   (d)   The airport master plan is a very useful document to incorporate into
the local comprehensive planning process and subsequent local land use
policies. The Bellefontaine Regional Airport Master Plan and ALP were updated
in 2006.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.12 CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT PLANNING.
   (a)   Capital improvement programming is an important means by which
comprehensive planning is realized, and is vital to areas where large tracts of
vacant land have yet to be developed.
   (b)   Types of funding available to airport sponsors for capital improvement
programming include:
      (1)   United States Government
      (2)   State of Ohio
      (3)   Local
         A.   General obligation Bonds
         B.   Revenue Bonds
         C.   Private Financing
         D.   Nonprofit Corporation Bonds
         E.   Industrial Development Authority
         F.   Retained Revenues
            (Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.13 ZONING.
   Airport zoning is to be handled separately. The zoning issues will involve
airport Airspace Zoning and Land Use Zoning. Airspace Zoning will be
administered by the Logan County Commissioners and will extend beyond the City
corporation limit. The Land Use Zoning will be handled through the City's
Zoning Code and will address land within the City corporation.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
LEASE AGREEMENT GUIDELINES
954.14 AGRICULTURAL LEASE.
   (a)   The Bellefontaine Regional Airport has approximately 247 acres
available for agricultural use. These areas are not to be developed due to
proximity to the runway and clear zones.
   (b)   The City of Bellefontaine advertises for bids for lease of said
property for agricultural use. The bids are for a three year period.
   (c)   Agricultural lessees are required to conform with all airport safety
regulations and coordinate activities with the Airport Manager.
   (d)   A model Agricultural Lease is attached.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.15 LAND LEASE.
   (a)   The arrangements between the airport owner and those private agencies
seeking to offer commodities and services at the airport are to be expressed in
a contract. Since most of these contracts involve the right to occupy and use
designated premises, they will generally be in the form of a lease. As in any
such agreement the rental payments, terms of occupancy, privileges granted,
obligations assumed, and other considerations are a matter of bargaining and
negotiation between the parties. There are, however, some general principles
peculiar to the airport environment which should be given careful
consideration.
   (b)   If the prospective tenant contemplates a substantial capital
investment in hangars, fuel storage equipment, machinery, and store fixtures,
etc, he or she will seek a relatively long term lease in order to be able to
amortize his or her investment. It is to the advantage of the airport owner to
encourage such private development and to offer sufficient tenure to induce it.
On the other hand, aviation is dynamic and airports evolve and expand faster
than anticipated. In leasing airport property to commercial tenants, it would
be well to avoid leasing more than is reasonably required. Similarly the
granting of options (to lease land not yet needed) may well turn out to the be
the most regretted concession made during initial negotiations.
   (c)   A commercial tenant when contemplating a substantial investment at an
airport will naturally seek some form of protection from competition. The
airport owner if fact may be under considerable pressure during the
negotiations to lease airport premises under terms which guarantee an exclusive
monopoly. However, the City should realize that any exclusive right to conduct
an “aeronautical activity” could make the City ineligible for various forms of
Federal assistance. Federal law prohibits the granting of an exclusive right to
conduct an aeronautical activity at any airport on which Federal funds have
been expended. However, there are alternate legal means of giving adequate
protection to a commercial aeronautical enterprise at a public airport.
Advisory Circular 150/5190-A, Minimum Standards for Commercial Aeronautical
Activities on Public Airports, describes in detail how an airport owner may,
and should, enforce standards of quality and levels of service, including
capital equipment. Such standards are very effective in excluding marginal or
irresponsible competitive operations so there should be no compelling reason to
lease airport facilities on an exclusive basis. The legal prohibition against
airport monopolies does not apply to non-aeronautical activities such as
restaurants, taxicabs, limousines, etc.
   (d)   In negotiating a lease on airport premises, it is desirable to keep in
mind the nature of the rights and privileges to be conferred for the rentals or
other considerations to be paid. The following describe conditions that
aeronautical tenants usually seek when developing and negotiating a lease:
      (1)   The lease of specified premises for as long a term as it can.
      (2)   The right to conduct at those premises a wide range of activities
with as little restriction as possible.
      (3)   The rights, for itself and its customers, to use in common with
others the runways, taxiways, and other public facilities of the airport.
   (e)   A good lease will reflect thoughtful consideration of each of these
objectives.
      (1)   The lease of land or specific premises should be for a term long
enough to amortize the investment to which the tenant will be committed. It
should be for a firm rental rate. It should clearly spell out the respective
housekeeping and insurance responsibilities of each party. If renewal options
are contemplated there may be provision for the airport owner to terminate the
lease upon reimbursing the tenant for the unamortized value of installed
improvements. Above all, the lease should be consistent with the master plan
for phased airport development and land use.
      (2)   The agreement or lease should clearly identify what the tenant is
permitted to do. This represents a franchise right to conduct a business of
offering commodities and services to those attracted to the airport. It should
cite the applicable standards, codes, or ordinances covering the exercise of
the patronage at the airport.
   (f)   A model Land Lease Agreement is Attached.
   (g)   The price charged for land under the Agreement should reflect the
costs incurred
by the City with regard to acquisition and development and the costs to be
incurred by the Lessee with regard to improvements. Particular note should be
made of private improvements which may benefit the airport in general or if
excessive costs are associated with making the land accessible.
   (h)   Based upon other airport land use rates, costs incurred by the city
and other development considerations the recommended cost per square foot for
land lease at the Bellefontaine Regional Airport is between twenty to forty
cents (.20-.40).
   (i)   The Airport Minimum Standards should be adhered to with regard to land
leases and private development. However, each lease may present unique
circumstances supporting a deviation from the Minimum Standards.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)
954.16 T-HANGAR LEASES.
   (a)   In 2006 there are three (3) T-Hangar buildings housing twenty eight
(28) individual T-Hangar units. Two buildings house twenty (10 each) single-
engine aircraft units and one building houses eight (8) twin-engine aircraft
units.
   (b)   The T-Hangars are owned and operated by the City of Bellefontaine. The
Airport Manager shows the units to potential lessees and maintains the common
areas as part of his regular duties, but does not share in any rental revenue
derived therefrom.
   (c)   T-Hangar rental fees were first established in 2002 for the single-
engine aircraft units. In July, 2006 fees were adjusted for inflation based
upon the Midwest Consumer Price Index. Also, fees were established at that time
for the twin-engine aircraft units.
   (d)   It is recommended that the T-Hangar Rental Fees be examined every
three to five years for warranted increases based upon the Midwest Consumer
Price Index for all categories.
   (e)   Future T-Hangar development is illustrated in Exhibit B and discussed
in the Airport Master Plan.
   (f)   A model T-Hangar Rental Agreement is attached.
(Ord. 07-01. Passed 2-15-07.)

vehicles which shall be operated by members of the Fire Department.

   The operation and maintenance of the ambulance vehicle(s) shall be under the
direct supervision of the Fire Chief who shall organize and train personnel in
the operation of such vehicle(s) and its equipment.
(Ord. 91-18. Passed 3-12-91.)

   The territories served by the ambulance shall be limited to the corporate
boundaries of the City of Bellefontaine and to a radius of ten miles around the
City with the exception of the mutual aide agreements to which the City is a
party, and the transfer of persons from Mary Rutan Hospital to hospitals in
other cities.

   All persons availing themselves of the use of such emergency vehicle shall
be transported to the closest most appropriate medical facility in accordance
with the protocol provided by the medical director and as determined by the EMS
personnel. Further, persons may be transported from one hospital to another,
one facility to another, or to his/her home or care center as needed upon
request.
(Ord.  15-34. Passed 8-11-15.)
955.06 ADDITIONAL RULES.
   The Service-Safety Director is authorized to adopt additional rules,
regulations and charges in connection with the use of such ambulance vehicle
not inconsistent with the terms of this chapter and subject to the approval of

(Ord. 91-18. Passed 3-12-91.)
955.07 DEPOSIT OF FUNDS.
   All fees and charges paid to the City from the operation of such emergency
vehicle(s) shall be deposited in a special account to be known as "Ambulance
Fund"; and such funds shall be used solely for the purpose of maintenance,
operation and replacement of the ambulances and ambulance equipment, and for
personnel to operate and maintain said emergency vehicle(s) or ambulances.
(Ord. 05-105. Passed 12-13-05.)
955.08 BILLING AND COLLECTION OF FEES.
   (a)   All fees charged for the use of such ambulance and/or emergency
vehicle(s) shall be billed and collected by the Fire Department and all
receipts and/or money collected shall be deposited directly to the Ambulance
Fund with such deposits reported to the Mayor’s Office.
   (b)   All billing procedures for such services shall be the responsibility
of the Fire Chief who shall also be responsible for the collection of such
accounts and such accounts to be charged off due to inability of collection
thereof will be the responsibility of the Fire Chief and any and all such
charge-off figures will be reported on a monthly basis to the Service-Safety
Director and will be subject to his/her approval.
   (c)   If an ambulance statement has been paid for by the patient or receiver
of services or by someone on their behalf and then is again paid by Medicare,
Ohio Medicaid or any insurance company, the Fire Chief and/or the Service-
Safety Director will endorse said check and mail it to the patient and/or
receiver of services. There shall be a cover letter to the patient and a copy
of such cover letter attached to the original statement.
(Ord. 01-95. Passed 12-11-01.)
955.09 MUNICIPAL EMPLOYEES EXEMPT FROM CHARGES.
   All employees of the City shall be exempt from paying any base rate or
additional charges for any such emergency vehicle service, that is not covered
by insurance, within the corporation limits of the City for themselves and/or
members of their immediate family.
(Ord. 15-34. Passed 8-11-15.)

CHAPTER 959
Curbside Recycling
959.01   Program established.
959.02   Definitions.
959.03   Separation of recyclables from solid waste.
959.04   Weekly collection; bins.
959.05   Scavenging prohibited.
959.06   Curbside service; handicapped persons.
959.07   User fee.
959.08   Powers of Service-Safety Director.
959.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Garbage and refuse collection - see S.U. & P.S. Ch.
959
 
959.01 PROGRAM ESTABLISHED.
   (a)   There is hereby established a program for the collection of recyclable
materials, including but not limited to aluminum cans, newspapers, plastic and
glass containers from the residences of the City of Bellefontaine. Such
collections shall be made periodically under the supervision of the Service-
Safety Director.
 
   (b)   The program of collection and disposal of recyclable materials by the
City is hereby declared to be a public utility. The services provided for in
this chapter shall be rendered to all citizens upon compliance with all City
regulations pertaining to such utility and upon payment of the rates as may be
provided by Council as the same may be amended from time to time.
(Ord. 91-61. Passed 8-13-91.)
 
959.02 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   "Director" means the Service-Safety Director of the City.
   (b)   "Housing Unit" means a place of abode for a family, person or persons
living separately or together as an independent family and referring to both
single and multifamily residential units.
   (c)   "Recycling bin" means a storage unit provided by the City in which
recyclable materials is to be placed and commingled by the occupants of each
housing unit, unless served by other storage units. Such bin must be approved
by the Director.
   (d)   "Recycling Contractor" means the contractor authorized by the City for
the collection, transporting and delivery to market of recyclable materials.
   (e)   "Recyclable materials" means non-ferrous (aluminum) cans, newspapers,
clear; green and brown glass bottles, and PET (1) and HDPE (2) plastic
containers.
      (Ord. 91-61. Passed 8-13-91.)
 
959.03 SEPARATION OF RECYCLABLES FROM SOLID WASTE.
   All solid waste set out for collection by the owner or occupant of every
housing unit, as defined herein, within the City shall be set out for the
collection so that recyclable materials are separated from the solid waste,
except if the recyclable material is employed in the disposal of other solid
waste or if the recyclable material has been contaminated. Newspapers shall be
considered clean and uncontaminated if they have not been exposed to substances
or conditions rendering them unusable for recycling. Residents may wrap solid
waste in used newspapers and discard same with regular solid waste, even if
such wrapping does not render the newspapers unusable for recycling.
(Ord. 91-61. Passed 8-13-91.)
 
959.04 WEEKLY COLLECTION; BINS.
   (a)   Collection of recyclable materials shall be weekly and such materials
shall be set out for collection by the occupant of each housing unit on the
street curb on the day designated by the Recycling Contractor.
 
   (b)   All recyclable materials shall be placed in the recycling bin.
(Ord. 91-61. Passed 8-13-91.)
 
959.05 SCAVENGING PROHIBITED.
   (a)   Upon the placement of recyclable materials at the street curb for
collection by the recycling contractor the recyclable material shall become the
property of the City.
 
   (b)   During the twenty-four hour period commencing at 6:00 p.m. on any day
preceding a day designated for collection of recyclable material; no person,
other than an authorized recycling collection contractor, shall remove
recyclable material which has been placed at the curb. Any and each such
removal of recyclable material in violation hereof from one or more designated
recycling collection locations shall constitute a separate and distinct offense
punishable as provided in this chapter.
 
   (c)   Nothing in this chapter shall limit the right of an individual person,
organization or other entity to donate, sell or otherwise dispose of recyclable
material, provided that any such disposal is in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter.
(Ord. 91-61. Passed 8-13-91.)
 
959.06 CURBSIDE SERVICE; HANDICAPPED PERSONS.
   On the regularly scheduled collection day, persons residing in housing units
as defined herein shall place the recycling bin at the curb in front of the
housing unit. Carry-out service shall be provided by the recycling contractor
for housing units of handicapped, disabled, impaired persons or persons who are
otherwise precluded from or physically incapable of placing recycling bins at
curbside.
(Ord. 91-61. Passed 8-13-91.)
 
959.07 USER FEE.
   No user fee shall be charged for the recyclable material collection service
until such time as Council determines it necessary.
(Ord. 91-61. Passed 8-13-91.)
 
959.08 POWERS OF SERVICE-SAFETY DIRECTOR.
   The Service-Safety Director shall have full and complete authority to make
such other rules and regulations, not inconsistent herewith, pertaining to the
collection for recycling of recyclable material, as well as to the
administration thereof, as may be deemed advisable.
(Ord. 91-61. Passed 8-13-91.)
 
959.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with the provisions of Section
959.03 and
959.05, is guilty of a minor misdemeanor and shall be fined not more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be deemed committed each
day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 94-80. Passed 9-27-94.)
 
 
 
CHAPTER 961
Wireless Communication Facilities
